summary: Healthcare Navigation Help is a community support web app/program for individuals and families everywhere (not limited to Leominster, MA or Massachusetts). It helps users find affordable care, understand insurance, prepare for appointments, manage medical bills, access financial assistance programs, and build healthcare advocacy skills. The vision is to expand from local to national/global impact.
architectural_notes: Program focuses on real-life navigation skills and actionable tools, not just informational content
Vision includes scalability from local/regional to national and global reach
Community resource finder should support geolocation (with user permission) and manual zip code/address input to find nearby resources, replacing the hardcoded Leominster, MA location
Location-based resource search should return real nearby places relevant to the user's entered location (city, zip, or address), not just filter hardcoded local data
App should use general/universal language throughout — avoid hardcoding references to Leominster, MA or Massachusetts in UI text, descriptions, and informational content

existing_features.title: Create a Hero/Home section that introduces Healthcare Navigation Help, states the mission ('No one should miss medical care because the system is confusing, overwhelming, or hard to afford'), and provides clear calls-to-action to explore tools and resources.

Build a 'Find Affordable Care' resource finder that presents categorized healthcare service options (urgent care, routine visits, specialized treatment, community health centers) with descriptions helping users understand where to go for different health needs.

Build an Insurance Terms & Coverage Explainer section with a searchable glossary of common insurance terms (e.g., deductible, copay, premium, network, EOB) and short plain-language definitions to help first-time insurance users understand their coverage.

Create an interactive Appointment Preparation Checklist tool that guides users through what questions to ask, what documents to bring, and how to advocate for their needs before a doctor or hospital visit. Users can check off items and see their progress.

Build a Medical Bill Guide section that explains how to read a medical bill, how to identify common billing errors, and what payment plan or financial assistance options are typically available. Present content in a step-by-step format.

Create a Financial Assistance Programs finder that lists public health coverage programs and hospital financial aid options (e.g., MassHealth, Health Safety Net, hospital charity care) with brief descriptions and guidance on how to apply.

Build a Community Resource Map section that lists local healthcare resources in Leominster and surrounding Massachusetts communities, including community health centers, free clinics, and support services, displayed as a structured directory with name, type, and contact/access information.

Create a Step-by-Step Navigation Tools section featuring guided healthcare journey flows (e.g., 'I need care but have no insurance', 'I received a confusing bill', 'I need to find a specialist'). Each journey presents a linear sequence of steps with explanations and recommended actions.

Build an Educational Resources & Workshops section that showcases available educational guides, upcoming or recorded learning sessions, and advocacy skill-building content. Include a listing for workshops with title, description, and audience.

Add a persistent navigation bar and an About/Vision page describing the program mission, who it serves (families, youth, first-time insurance users, people with confusing bills), the service area (Leominster, MA and surrounding Massachusetts communities), and the long-term vision of expanding impact regionally and nationally.

Apply a warm, trustworthy, and approachable visual theme throughout the app. Use a calming teal-green and warm white color palette with clear readable typography. The design should feel welcoming, not clinical — conveying community support rather than a hospital or insurance company. Enforce this style consistently across all pages and components.

Integrate Internet Identity login into the app. Add a login/logout button in the Navigation bar that triggers the Internet Identity authentication flow. Display the user's principal or a 'Signed In' indicator when authenticated. Use the existing useInternetIdentity hook and useActor hook already present in the codebase.

Remove all workshop-related content from the app. This includes: removing the EducationPage workshops listing section (workshop cards rendered via WorkshopCard), removing the WorkshopCard component from active use, removing the Education/Workshops route and nav link from App.tsx and Navigation.tsx, and removing workshop-related backend query calls from useQueries.ts. Educational guides and advocacy content not tied to workshops may remain if they exist separately.

Add a static HTML file (e.g., verification.html or a custom named file) to the frontend public directory so it is served as a standalone page at a direct URL path. The file should be a minimal, valid HTML document. If the user has a specific filename or content in mind, they should provide it; otherwise, create a placeholder named 'site-verification.html' with a basic HTML structure and a comment indicating it can be customized.

Update the Community Resources page (ResourcesPage.tsx) to replace the hardcoded Leominster, MA location assumption with a location-aware finder. Add a location bar at the top of the page with two options: (1) a 'Use My Location' button that requests the browser's Geolocation API (with permission) to detect the user's current coordinates, and (2) a text input field where the user can manually type a zip code or street address. When a location is provided (either via geolocation or manual entry), display it as the active search context (e.g., 'Showing resources near: 01453' or 'Showing resources near your current location'). If no location has been provided yet, show a prompt encouraging the user to enter their location. The location bar should be styled consistently with the existing warm teal-green theme.

On the Community Resources page, once a location is active (either from geolocation coordinates or a manually entered zip code/address), filter or sort the displayed resource directory to prioritize entries closest to the user's location. For zip code input, match resources whose zip code matches or is geographically nearby. For geolocation coordinates, sort resources by proximity. Display a note to the user if no resources are found near their entered location.

In ResourcesPage.tsx, when the user submits a location (zip code, city name like 'Miami', or any address) via the manual text input in the LocationBar, use the browser's native fetch to call a free geocoding API (e.g., Nominatim/OpenStreetMap at https://nominatim.openstreetmap.org/search) to resolve the entered text into latitude/longitude coordinates. Store those resolved coordinates as the active location context so the existing proximity-sort logic can rank resources by distance from those coordinates.

Extend the community resource data in both the backend (backend/main.mo) and the static fallback data in ResourcesPage.tsx to include latitude and longitude fields for each resource entry. Populate realistic coordinates for the existing Leominster-area resources (e.g., Leominster, MA is approximately lat 42.5251, lng -71.7598). Update the CommunityResource type in Motoko to add optional lat and lng Float fields, and update the initialization data accordingly. On the frontend, use these lat/lng fields (when available) in the proximity-sort calculation instead of relying solely on zip code comparison.

Update locationUtils.ts to replace or augment the zip-code numeric comparison approach with a haversine distance calculation that uses lat/lng coordinates. When the active location has coordinates (from geolocation or resolved geocoding), sort all resources with known coordinates by their haversine distance from the active location, ascending. Resources with no coordinates fall to the bottom. Display the computed distance (e.g., '~3 miles away') next to each resource entry in the ResourceDirectoryItem component when a location is active.

Create a new 'Healthcare Challenges' informational page (e.g., ChallengesPage.tsx) that educates users about common healthcare problems and obstacles people face when navigating the system. Include sections covering topics such as: understanding why healthcare is confusing and expensive, common barriers to care (cost, lack of insurance, language, transportation), what to do when you can't afford care, how to avoid common pitfalls with insurance and billing, and tips for advocating for yourself or a family member. Present content in a clear, accessible format using cards, callout boxes, and short readable sections consistent with the existing warm teal-green design system.
Add a navigation link to the new Healthcare Challenges page in Navigation.tsx and include a quick-link card for it on the HomePage so users can discover it from the main entry points of the app.

In ResourcesPage.tsx, remove all hardcoded Leominster/Massachusetts resource entries from the static fallback data array and replace them with generically named entries (e.g., 'Local Community Health Center', 'Free Clinic', 'Federally Qualified Health Center') with no city/state-specific addresses or zip codes. Remove any latitude/longitude values tied specifically to the Leominster area and replace with null/omitted values on the fallback entries, since their location is unknown without user input.

In AboutPage.tsx, remove all references to 'Leominster', 'Massachusetts', 'Leominster, MA', and 'surrounding Massachusetts communities' from the page text, mission statements, service area descriptions, and vision section. Replace them with universal language such as 'your community', 'communities across the country', 'people everywhere', or 'wherever you are'. The long-term vision text should reflect a mission applicable to all users regardless of location.

Audit all remaining frontend files — including HomePage.tsx, Navigation.tsx, HeroSection.tsx, FindCarePage.tsx, FinancialAssistancePage.tsx, ChallengesPage.tsx, MedicalBillGuidePage.tsx, InsuranceGuidePage.tsx, NavigationToolsPage.tsx, AppointmentPrepPage.tsx, and any other page or component files — and remove every occurrence of 'Leominster', 'Massachusetts', and 'MA' (used as a state reference). Replace with neutral, universal language (e.g., 'your area', 'local community', 'nationwide', 'across the country', or simply omit location qualifiers where not needed). Also update index.html page title or meta descriptions if they reference these locations.

In FinancialAssistancePage.tsx, update the static fallback list of financial assistance programs to replace or supplement Massachusetts-specific programs (MassHealth, Health Safety Net, Mass General Brigham charity care, etc.) with generically named equivalents applicable anywhere in the US (e.g., 'State Medicaid Program', 'Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP)', 'Hospital Charity Care / Financial Assistance', 'Community Health Center Sliding Scale', 'Prescription Assistance Programs'). Update program descriptions to use universal language referencing 'your state' or 'your local hospital' rather than specific Massachusetts entities.

Perform a full codebase audit and remove every occurrence of the words 'Leominster' and 'Massachusetts' (including abbreviation 'MA' used as a state reference) from all frontend source files — pages, components, hooks, utilities, index.html, and any other file under the frontend directory. Replace location-specific text with neutral, universal language (e.g., 'your community', 'your area', 'local community', 'across the country', or omit the qualifier entirely). Files to check include but are not limited to: HomePage.tsx, Navigation.tsx, HeroSection.tsx, FindCarePage.tsx, FinancialAssistancePage.tsx, ChallengesPage.tsx, MedicalBillGuidePage.tsx, InsuranceGuidePage.tsx, NavigationToolsPage.tsx, AppointmentPrepPage.tsx, AboutPage.tsx, ResourcesPage.tsx, and index.html.

Create a new informational page (e.g., RightsPage.tsx) titled 'Know Your Healthcare Rights' that educates users about their fundamental rights as patients and healthcare consumers. Include sections covering: (1) the right to receive emergency care regardless of insurance status or ability to pay, (2) the right to receive an itemized bill and dispute charges, (3) the right to request an interpreter or language assistance services, (4) the right to access and obtain copies of your medical records, (5) the right to a second opinion, (6) the right to appeal insurance denials, and (7) protections against surprise billing. Present content using cards, callout boxes, and short readable sections consistent with the existing warm teal-green design system (matching the style of ChallengesPage.tsx and other informational pages in the app).

Register the new Rights page as a route in App.tsx (e.g., at path '/healthcare-rights') and add a navigation link for it in Navigation.tsx so users can discover and access it from the persistent site-wide nav bar. Additionally, add a quick-link card for the Rights page on the HomePage quick-links grid so users can find it from the main entry point of the app.
